t: Song of Solomon 8
If*pn only you were to me like a brother, who*ld was nursed at my mother’s breasts! Then,*ln if I found you outside, I*ld would kiss you, and*ld no one would despise me.
I*ln would lead you and*ld bring you to my mother’s house— she*ld who has taught me. I*ln would give you spiced wine to drink, the*ld nectar of my pomegranates.
His*ln left arm is under my head and*ld his right arm embraces me.
Daughters*ln of Jerusalem, I charge you: Do*ld not arouse or awaken love until*ld it so desires.
Friends
Who*pn is this coming up from the wilderness leaning*ld on her beloved?
She
Under*pn the apple tree I roused you; there*ld your mother conceived you, there*ld she who was in labor gave you birth.
Place*ln me like a seal over your heart, like*ld a seal on your arm; for*ln love is as strong as death, its*ld jealousy unyielding as the grave. It*ln burns like blazing fire, like*ld a mighty flame.
Many*ln waters cannot quench love; rivers*ld cannot sweep it away. If*ln one were to give all*ld the wealth of one’s house for love, it*ld would be utterly scorned.
Friends
We*pn have a little sister, and*ld her breasts are not yet grown. What*ln shall we do for our sister on*ld the day she is spoken for?
If*ln she is a wall, we*ld will build towers of silver on her. If*ln she is a door, we*ld will enclose her with panels of cedar.
She
I*pn am a wall, and*ld my breasts are like towers. Thus*ln I have become in his eyes like*ld one bringing contentment.
Solomon*ln had a vineyard in Baal Hamon; he*ld let out his vineyard to tenants. Each*ln was to bring for its fruit a*ld thousand shekels of silver.
But*ln my own vineyard is mine to give; the*ld thousand shekels are for you, Solomon, and*ld two hundred are for those who tend its fruit.
He
You*pn who dwell in the gardens with*ld friends in attendance, let*ld me hear your voice!
She
Come*pn away, my beloved, and*ld be like a gazelle or*ln like a young stag on*ld the spice-laden mountains.
